description.narrative:
IRRI will carry out research as outlined below in a select number of refugee hosting districts to ensure a deeper understanding of the complex dynamics affecting communities in refugee hosting districts in Uganda.
On tensions between host communities and refugees, IRRI will document recent incidents, through individual interviews with those involved and with witnesses, and will conduct focusgroup discussions with both refugee and host communities to garner a better understanding of the issues that are currently creatingor are likely to create tensions between both groups, including the impact of humanitarian and development interventions and decisions by local governmental actors. Sufficient attention will be devoted to the gender-differentiated impact and the link to pressure on natural resources. Attention will also be given to understanding the interventions of existing formal and informal mechanisms forconflict resolution, such as traditional/cultural leaders.
On inter-refugee tensions, IRRIwill document recent incidents by interviewing actors and witnesses and will conduct focus groups with different communities to understand the deeper conflict dynamics. Researchers will suggest policy options that both allow humanitarian actors to managethe protection risks in the settlements, as well as mitigate dynamics that could increase the polarisation between different groups. Researchers will also consider the current and potential roles of community leadership structures, traditional leaders, NGOs and CBOs in addressing tensions among refugees and supporting long-term solutions.
On cross-border spill-over from South Sudan, researchers will document recent incidents, such as the incursions and recruitment by South Sudanese armed actors, by interviewing witnesses, including refugees, Ugandan citizens and local authorities, to document any patterns.
A cross-cutting theme throughout the research will be understanding the gendered nature of theconflict dynamics, including: the gendered natureof conflict triggers; the gendered impacts of conflict; and a gendered analysis ofthe possible conflict prevention and resolution strategies that exist or are proposed by the research. Particular attention will beplayed to ensure that research design allows for documentation and analysis of issues such as sexual violence, which often under-reported due to victim#s fear and associated social stigma.
Primary data will be collected through qualitative interviews with a cross-section of host and refugeecommunities and other stakeholders. Interviews will be conducted through focus group discussions and individual interviews with identified key informants. Researchers will conduct workshops in the refugee hosting districts to present and discuss preliminary research findings and draw on additional recommendations from on-the-ground stakeholders. One workshop will be conducted at the national level to compile perspectives different actors including UN agencies, government representatives and other key stakeholders such as the Interreligious Council representatives, NGOs and cultural leaders from the different regions in Uganda.

participating-org.narrative: IRRI was founded in 2004 to inform and improve responses to the cycles of violence and displacement that are at the heart of large-scale human rights violations. Their vision is a world where every person feels safe and secure, be that in their own homesor elsewhere. Over the last 14 years, IRRI has developed a holistic approach to the protection of human rights before, during, and in the aftermath of displacement, by focusing on: 1) identifying the violations that cause displacement and exile, 2) protecting the rights ofthose who are displaced, and 3) ensuring the solutions to their displacement are durable, rights respecting, safe and timely. IRRI works to ensure the voices of the displaced and conflict affected communities are not only heard butheeded at the international level through evidence-based advocacy that is built on solid field based research and analysis. IRRI registered as a non-profit organisation in the US, the UK and Uganda with a board of seven, headed up by the Nigeria-based Chair, Chidi Odinkalu, and the Uganda-based Vice-Chair, Salima Namusobya, with the other board members based in the UK, US and Tanzania.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security
